bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Willys M. Monroe, June 10, 1923

div1.p: Carter responds to Monroe's letter raising questions about the endemic yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Willys M. Monroe, June 10, 1923
div1.opener:
Book
Monroe
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 10. 1923.
Dr. Willys M. Monroe.
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Monroe:
div1.p:
Your letter without date received. I have delayed answering it,
because I have no time in the week to answer any personal mail.

1/ I can't think that you gained the impression from anything
that I ever wrote that the total population of a region in which yel-
low fever was permanently endemic must be at least equal to that of a
single large town sufficient for such endemicity. It may be, but since
the fever would spread more slowly in such a region it would take
longer to immunize and hence be less apt to die out spontaneously.

2/ Your point that yellow fever would continue in a community
longer in proportion as active aegypti approach the critical number--
being, of course, in excess of it--is well taken, remembering, how-
ever, that the critical number is sufficient to continue the disease.
It has no other definition. If the temperature falls then so as to
bring aegypti very near this limit, there is always a chance of it
passing below it and extinguishing the fever. In Tampico, for instance,
whether from diminished production of Stegomyia in winter or from the
increased immunization of men in summer, yellow fever has frequently
disappeared for as much as three or four years at a time. The same
has been true of Matanzas: Neuvitas and a number of ports on the
the
2
north of Cuba.

3/ So far as the number of susceptible people necessary to con-
tinue the fever is concerned, one cannot tell anything of this unless
he knew the movement of them, for instance: allowing four days for the
average incubation in man and three days afterward for the time in which
he is infective to mosquitoes and--say--42 days for the life of the mos-
quito, if we had a single house with infected mosquitoes in it to begin
with, the introduction therein of a susceptible man every 49 days (he
to stay in the house) would continue the fever in that place indefinitely.

Naturally, of course, one can never space either the time of ar-
rival of susceptible people or ensure their going into an infected house,
but I think in general we might say that the introduction of eight sus-
ceptible men per annum, living as they would live, would not suffice to
continue yellow fever in a village.

4/ Spite of the altitude of Bucaramanga, I profoundly doubt if
yellow fever would be apt to be permanently endemic in such a place. It
did not remain so in Heredia or San Domingo in Costa Rica, nor in La
Mesa in Colombia, in all three of which it spread slowly, on account
(one feels sure) of sparcity of Stegomyia. I would certainly be willing
to take my chance for even spontaneous elimination with a place which was
so near the limit of Stegomyia breeding some months of the year than a
place where the contrary condition existed. Compare, for instance,
Monterey, which has frequently cleaned itself of yellow fever and Yucatan
where it continued a long time.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
